chapter.title: Input Methods
chapter.para: Input methods are an operating system component that allows any data, such as keyboard strokes or mouse movements, to be received as input. In this way users can enter characters and symbols not found on their input devices. Using an input method is obligatory for any language that has more graphemes than there are keys on the keyboard.
The following input methods are available in NixOS:

listitem.para: Fcitx: A customizable lightweight input method.
Nabi: A Korean input method based on XIM.
Uim: The universal input method, is a library with a XIM bridge.

section.title: IBus

listitem.para: Anthy (ibus-engines.anthy): Anthy is a system for Japanese input method. It converts Hiragana text to Kana Kanji mixed text.
m17n (ibus-engines.m17n): m17n is an input method that uses input methods and corresponding icons in the m17n database.
mozc (ibus-engines.mozc): A Japanese input method from Google.
Table (ibus-engines.table): An input method that load tables of input methods.

section.title: Fcitx
section.para: Fcitx is an input method framework with extension support. It has three built-in Input Method Engine, Pinyin, QuWei and Table-based input methods.
The following snippet can be used to configure Fcitx:
i18n.inputMethod.fcitx.engines is optional and can be used to add extra Fcitx engines.

listitem.para: Anthy (fcitx-engines.anthy): Anthy is a system for Japanese input method. It converts Hiragana text to Kana Kanji mixed text.
Chewing (fcitx-engines.chewing): Chewing is an intelligent Zhuyin input method. It is one of the most popular input methods among Traditional Chinese Unix users.
m17n (fcitx-engines.m17n): m17n is an input method that uses input methods and corresponding icons in the m17n database.
mozc (fcitx-engines.mozc): A Japanese input method from Google.
